The motor manufacturing company currently employs nearly 7,755 people and produces around 519,000 cars each year &ndash 55 percent of which for the European market.Brexit news: Mr Tsuruoka warned a no deal Brexit could push companies to reconsider their place  (Image: BBC)The Japanese carmaker has warned Britain of the &ldquoserious implications a no deal Brexit could have on the British manufacturing sector.The company said in a statement in early October: &ldquoToday we are among those companies with major investment in the UK who are still waiting for clarity on what the future trading relationship between the UK and the EU will look like.As a sudden change from those rules to the rules of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) will have serious implications for British industry, we urge UK and EU negotiators to work collaboratively towards an orderly, balanced Brexit that will continue to encourage mutually beneficial trade.But Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to back any attempt by the UK to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP).The 11-nation bloc accounts for more than 13 percent of the world&rsquos wealth and includes Canada, Mexico, Vietnam and Australia.Brexiteers have touted the ability for the UK to strike global trade deals as one of the main benefits of leaving the EU.

story: The British MEP ridiculed Remain activist demanding a second vote on Brexit with a People's Vote March &ndash mocking the low turnout compared to the 2016 referendum.Latest estimates suggest nearly 700,000 Britons converged in London last weekend to protest Theresa May's refusal to hold a new ballot on the final withdrawal deal.Mr Woolfe condemned the anti-democratic participants, taking particular aim at celebrity protesters: Yes, our own anti-democrats were out in full force this weekend.Tuscan villas were vacated en masse as the Remoaner geriatrics coordinated their travels down to London to fight for their future. They were joined by celebrities whose respect for the British public has expired along with a raft of Islington intellectuals fighting for their beloved United States of Europe.                Former Chancellor trashes calls for second Brexit referendum                Sadiq Khan under attack for 'SABOTAGING' Brexit with Michel Barnier meYes, do you hear the numbers? All 700,000 of them.The march was attended by key figures in the anti-Brexit campaign, including Labour peer Andrew Adonis, Tory rebel Anna Soubry and actor Steve Coogan.After questioning the estimates, Mr Woolfe added: The Remoaners have been clinging to the gospel of 700,000 seamlessly oblivious to the fact that 700,000 is just a little bit smaller than the 17.4 million voters who voted to leave.The &ldquoPeople&rsquos Vote is pegged as the public having a &ldquofinal say on the deal negotiated by the Government.Brexit news: Mr Woolfe blasted 'anti-democratic Remoaners geriatrics' for marching in London (Image: *YOUTUBESteven Woolfe)Prime Minister May has clearly outlined there will not be another referendum on cutting ties with the EU, saying it would be a &ldquobetrayal of British voters.At the Tory Party conference earlier this month, Mrs May said: &ldquoThere are plenty of prominent people British politics, in parliament and out of it, who wants to stop Brexit in its tracks.Their latest plan is to call a second referendum. They call it a &lsquopeople's vote&rsquo, but we had a people's vote and the people chose to leave.London Mayor Sadiq Khan started the march and delivered an address to the crowd, saying: &ldquoWhat&rsquos really important is that those that say that a public vote is undemocratic, is unpatriotic, realise the fact the exact opposite is the truth.&ldquoWhat could be more democratic, what could be more British, than trusting the judgement of the British people.

title: Brexit news update Theresa May leadership Brexit final deal UK Parliament
story: Speaking to Bloomberg, Professor Richard Whitman of the University of Kent claimed the Prime Minister will be able to convince Tory rebels to hold fire until the end of the Brexit negotiations.&nbspBut as Theresa May will come back to Parliament with the finalised deal reached with Brussels, she will be faced with the moment of maximum danger of a leadership challenged by her fellow party members, Professor Whitman has claimed.&nbspThe International Relations lecturer said: &ldquoI think the problem that she really has now is when it comes to the crunch point.&ldquoClearly she is in a position in which she&rsquos able to get her critics to hold fire in terms of the moment in which they really have the chance to stick the boot in.                British MEP blasts May's failure to allow UK to take back control                Brexiteer MEP mocks 'REMOANER GERIATRICS' seeking to subvert Brexit&ldquoAnd that moment hasn&rsquot come yet. But as she finalises the deal with the EU and when she comes back to Parliament with a package, that&rsquos going to be the point of maximum danger for her.&ldquoObviously that&rsquos the issue that is really going to define her premiership.The Chatham House Associate Fellow argued potential Conservative candidates would not be prepared to replace Theresa May before March 2019 as they would have to pick up the negotiations from the Prime Minister's Chequers proposals and inevitably work on that as the starting point of their premiership.He said: &ldquoWho would want the job now? And who would want the job basically picking up the deal that she&rsquos done or the deal that she&rsquos moved along ad try to sell that as a starting point for their new leadership?&ldquoSo I think it&rsquos very, very difficult to imagine a situation between now and when the deal is done with the EU - assuming a deal can be done - that you would have a leadership challenge come to the forum.Brexit news: May will face a leadership challenge at the end of the talks, claims Prof. Whitman (Image: )&ldquoI think most of the candidates who are preparing for a leadership challenge are really preparing to pick things up after her running into difficulties in Parliament.Professor Whitman's comments come as&nbspthe Prime Minister appeared to have seen off the threat of an imminent leadership challenge on Wednesday evening after Tory MPs put on a noisy show of support at a crunch backbench meeting.Mrs May was greeted by desk banging and thumping on wooden panelling - traditional indications of approval among Tory MPs - at the weekly gathering of the party's powerful 1922 Committee at Westminster.And while she faced a string of probing questions about her approach to the&nbspBrexit&nbsptalks, an attempt to trigger a vote of no-confidence in her leadership failed to materialise.Theresa May's allies insisted she had won the room and hoped the recent spate of speculation about coup plot had been laid to rest.One source close to the Prime Minister said: It was very supportive.But some critics complained the meeting had been staged managed by party whips.Mrs May faced the meeting of the 1922 Committee - made up off all the party's backbench MPs - following angry criticism of her concessions to the EU from Eurosceptics.MPs expecting a vote of no confidence in Mrs May&rsquos leadership were left disappointed. Rumours had swept Westminster in recent days that 1922 Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady had received at least 48 letters demanding the move, enough to trigger a confidence vote under party rules.

story: Lewis Hamilton has backed the young Schumacher  (Image: )Schumacher Junior, 19, who is the son of the seven-time Formula 1 champion Michael, took a 347-point lead at the weekend in the European F3 series.Lewis Hamilton said to formula1: &ldquoSo there will 100 percent be a Schumacher back in Formula 1, partly because of the name, but secondly because he's doing a great job.&ldquoHe's obviously got a lot of talent as his Dad had, just like Keke and Nico Rosberg, just like when Fernando has kids I'm sure an Alonso will be here again.Mick was only 14 when he was with his father in the French Alps in 2013 when the F1 legend suffered life-changing head injuries following a ski accident.                Lewis Hamilton: How &lsquoincredible&rsquo Brit can equal Michael SchumacherOfficials updates from Schumacher&rsquos family have been scarce and it is believed he still remains in his Switzerland home.After his own F3 triumph, Mick said: &ldquoIt's a slightly unreal feeling - I'm absolutely delighted.&ldquoI still can't quite believe it.Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said: &ldquoHis performance in the second half of the season was therefore all the more impressive.Schumacher is taking after his father with his F1 talent  (Image: )&ldquoHe has shown that he has what it takes and that he can become one of the greats in our sport.Former F1 winner Gerhard Berger said: &ldquoMick has the racing genes of Michael.&ldquoIf he can continue to deliver performances like these, he will find his way into F1.Schumacher has been in a coma since his ski accident  (Image: )The Spanish Formula One racing driver Fernando Alonso has also backed Schumacher.Alonso said: &ldquoYou only see the results from the outside and he has a great talent and he will be good for the sport, to have the Schumacher name again in F1.Let&rsquos see what the future brings, not putting extra pressure on him which I&rsquom sure he has enough already. Let time decide.Mick Schumacher is yet to decide on his 2019 move and both GP3 and F2 are possible option for the young racing driver.

title: emmanuel macron news french president popularity poll latest
story: Only 29 percent of those surveyed reported a favourable opinion of Mr Macron in October, down from 32 percent last month, the BVA-Orange poll for RTL radio and La Tribune found.This is the lowest rating recorded by the pollster since the young leader took power 17 months ago.An overwhelming 70 percent expressed an unfavourable opinion of Mr Macron, up three percentage points from last month.The 40-year-old centrist is now more unpopular than his conservative Prime Minister Edouard Philippe, who is viewed favourably by 40 percent of the French.                Majority of people in France &lsquoUNHAPPY&rsquo with new cabinet, polls show                MACRON CRISIS: French leader&rsquos popularity stuck at low point - pollSome 57 percent of those polled said they had an unfavourable opinion of Mr Philippe, while three percent refused to answer.Erwan Lestrohan of pollster BVA said: &ldquoThe difference in popularity between Emmanuel Macron and Edouard Philippe has never been so important.&nbspAnother survey published on Wednesday confirmed the downward trend observed since the summer break.The Ifop poll for Le Point found that Mr Macron&rsquos satisfaction rating was &ldquostable at 26 percent, from 25 percent in September. Some 70 percent of respondents said they held an unfavourable opinion of him, up one point in one month.French President Emmanuel Macron (Image: Michele TantussiGetty Images)Conservative Prime Minister Edouard Philippe, more popular than the president (Image: ERIC FEFERBERGAFPGetty Images)The Ifop survey also found that Mr Philippe is less disliked than the president, with a dissatisfaction rating of 59 per cent, down four points from last month.&nbspMr Macron reshuffled his cabinet last week and made a rare televised address to reassure France that all is well after a scandal involving his ex-bodyguard and a string of ministerial resignations undermined his authority and put intense spotlight on his lack of political experience.But he hopes the cabinet rejig will steady his administration and inject new momentum into his reform agenda, which was put on hiatus as he weathered the storm.Plans to slash public spending and overhaul the wieldy pension and strained public healthcare systems as well as the constitution are all up next on Mr Macron&rsquos agenda.But there is increasing concern that the Macron administration is &ldquodestroying the French social model.Violence broke out last month as thousands of people demonstrated against his unpopular social reforms.The interior ministry said nine people were arrested in Paris, where one protester and a police officer were hurt after up to 300 anarchists stormed the rally, hurling projectiles at police, who hit back with teargas.Marchers carried banners saying they had had enough of austerity and unemployment, with many saying that Mr Macron&rsquos reforms will &ldquodisadvantage the weakest in society.Unions are planning further protests in the coming months on specific reforms but no specific dates have been set.The BVA-Orange poll of 1,090 people was carried out between October 24 and October 25, while the Ifop poll of 1,003 people was carried out between October 19 and October 20.

title: brexit news austria eu no deal sebastian kurz
story: Sebastian Kurz&rsquos government has formed a Brexit task force in case Britain leaves the EU without a deal.The Austrian Federal Economic Chamber (WKO) has also set up a checklist for companies areas of business that could potentially be hit hardest.Sectors targeted include goods traffic, industrial property rights, taxes and personnel.Businesses could face new hurdles when trading with the United Kingdom, it is feared.                Brexit news: Kurz urges EU leaders to 'BUDGE' position to seal UK deal                Austria has PLAN B for hard Brexit says KurzAustrian goods worth &pound3.46 billion (3.9 billion euros) were exported to Britain last year.This was offset by &pound2.2 billion (2.5 billion euros) in imports, for which full EU third-country tariffs would come into effect once the UK leaves the single bloc.Austrian Chancellor Gernot Bl&uumlmel said: Brexit will leave its mark on us.The former European Union (EU) Commissioner Franz Fischler has revealed he is pessimistic about the prospects of the Brexit negotiations&rsquo success.Franz Fischler, former EU commissioner, warns Brexit deal hopes are less than 50 per cent (Image: Getty)Mr Fischler said: The chance that we will see a reasonably negotiated solution come into force at the end of the day is currently not even at 50 percent.The supporters of a hard Brexit are still quite numerous in the British Parliament.Britain would continue to be treated as an EU Member State until the end of a December 31, 2020 transition period.The UK would remain in the EU single market and EU Customs Union for another 21 months after the March 2019 leaving date.Austrian chancellor Sebastian Kurz's government has rolled out new no-deal Brext measures (Image: Getty)But there are fears that a no-deal Brexit could spark chaos at Dover and Calais if French authorities add extra customs checks.Around 10,000 trucks a day pass through the ports, with around 2.6 million trucks rumbling through Dover in 2016.The goods account for 17 per cent of the UK&rsquos trade in goods, which is worth &pound119 billion.But queues of up to 17 miles could be created into the port if drivers are asked their reason for travelling.                Brexiteer MEP mocks 'REMOANER GERIATRICS' seeking to subvert BrexitEach extra check could add 50 seconds to a 25-second checking time, causing huge tailbacks, Home Secretary Sajid Javid warned the Cabinet this week.The termination of the free movement of persons may result in EU citizens needing UK residence and work permits.This month, France drew up a draft law to to rush though visas for British residents and holidaymakers in case Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal.Additional reporting by Monika Pallenberg.

title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: movember foundation cycle 6000miles london tokyo
story: But for most of us, as sobriety creeps back in, the time comes to dismiss our drunken ramblings as nothing more.Not the case for two mates from Hertfordshire, as a booze-filled decision to cycle around the world kick-started what promises to be the biggest challenge of their lives so far - and one which could save the lives of young men just like themselves.George Cullen, , and Ben Cook, , will embark on a ,-mile bicycle journey from London to Tokyo in March next year, all in the name of mens health.Known as The Hairy Handlebars, the pair will tackle the enormous trip with nothing more than their bikes, tents, some lycra and a whole lot of grit in the hope of raising £, for The Movember Foundation.Passing through  countries in total, their route takes them from Covent Garden through mainland Europe, following the Danube River to Istanbul, then on to Aktau in Central Asia.They will then continue through the Kazakhstan desert and across the famous Pamir Highway, before travelling around , miles through China and over to Osaka to reach their final destination in the Japanese capital.Having spent the early stages of their careers as a professional rugby player and a Royal Marine, respectively, both George and Ben are used to high-pressure situations.Even so, their cycle will pose a number of new challenges and dangers, as it sees them battle harsh weather, terrain, wildle and even potential terrorist activity during their six-month haul.Since setting their minds on the task more than year ago, the duo have linked up with the global mens health charity to become the faces of this years Movember campaign.But while they are passionate about raising funds for such a worthy cause, the journey itself came about due to a longing for something more.The desire to escape the monotony of everyday le and see the world in a unique way was initially the key motivator for their trip.As the idea evolved, it then became obvious that an adventure of this scale was the perfect opportunity to get people talking about the key health issues facing men just like themselves.Explaining their motives in their first blog, The Hairy Handlebars said: We see that mental health is an issue that is spiralling out of control in young men.Suicide in young males is a brutally high killer as men are forced into adhering to certain social norms that simply don’t reflect their true self.Now, of course, our adventure could be seen as the very embodiment of a testosterone-fuelled escapade.However, we are undertaking this for what can be construed as far more romantic reasons a desire to actually escape these norms that are creating the problem in the first place, coupled with a desire to see the world in the rawest way possible.As well as raising as much money as possible, perhaps we can provide inspiration to men to not adhere to the boundaries that have been set for them and steer them away from subsequent mental health issues.With plans to finish their trip in time for the  Rugby World Cup in Japan, the pair have also developed strong links with members of the rugby community.England captain Dylan Hartley is a keen supporter of the cause, and they have also joined up with Premiership side Harlequins charity foundation.And the pairs rugby club, National One side Bishops Stortford, will hold a Movember Round in support of their cause.Part of their fundraising effort will also go towards setting up a foundation in memory of Ian Williams, a former professional rugby player who passed away suddenly in February.The foundation will focus on mental health and cardiac issues in young athletes.George Cullen said: A huge motivation for us is the chance to raise awareness of mental health issues in men.As things stand, the ability for men to get things off their chest, a proven relief of mental health problems, is simply not where it needs to be.We have to get to a point where men are able to talk openly about their issues and seek help, whether from mates, family or a professional.We both recognise the fact that we have had our own issues, and as a result know the value of having people around you who will listen.We hope that we can do our own small bit in ensuring no man has to suffer in silence -that means getting one man to reach out to someone about their problems, then taking on our cycle will be worth it.The Hairy Handlebars hope to raise £, for The Movember Foundation. If you would like to donate, you can access their fundraising page here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. title: argentina exploit no deal brexit falklands britain
story: The country’s foreign minister Jorge Faurie said his country would use the situation to “enhance” its own diplomatic push to take over the islands.Talking to the , Mr Faurie said once the UK leaves the European Union, all EU treaties will no longer apply and member states wont be obliged to support the UK’s claim over the South Atlantic territory.He said: “Our planning for Las Malvinasis to have a negotiation that will enable stronger relations between the people on the islands and the people on the continent.“And we hope that the non Brexitsolution will enhance the possibility of that dialogue to be truly one with results.”Mr Faurie suggested Argentina could take advantage of looser diplomatic ties between the UK and EU as part of its ongoing bid to take control of the Falklands.Mr Faurie said: “If you think member states [of the EU] would not sustain the Malvinas claim in favour of the UK, we are there ... to talk, to negotiate, to see what would be the best solution for the people in the islands to be much more in touch with Argentina.”It comes amid growing uncertainty over the legal status of the UKs overseas territories.Under the EU’s  Lisbon Treaty, the Falkland Islands are a British overseas territory where EU rules apply.The EU’s Duty of Sincere Cooperation includes a a mutual legal obligation for the EU member states to help each other over any claims over sovereignty.Mr Faurie, on a visit to the UK, reiterated his position that the Falklands, which Britain went to war over in , should be integrated into mainland Argentina.UK Prime Minister Theresa May is due to meet Argentinian president Mauricio Macri at the G in Buenos Aires on November .This would be the first visit by a British prime minister to Argentina since Tony Blair in .

title: universal credit help paid fortnightly
story: But the Governments new flagship benefits system, which is being rolled out across the country, does have provisions where you can apply to get money more regularly instead.There are three types of help available for vulnerable Brits called alternative payment arrangements, which arent always known about.Claimants can arrange for their landlord to get their benefits paid directly, they can split their payments between a couple, or apply for more regular payments.These are offered for those in special circumstances, or for Brits who are considered more at risk and need extra help.Heres how you can get the additional supportyoure struggling on Universal Credit.The DWP can decide to pay you more frequentlyit thinks that you are in high need of it.This could include Brits with:You can speak to your work coachyou think you could be eligible, and identy the factors which apply. Being paid weekly only happens in very exceptional circumstances.The DWP make the final decision, and you cant appeal it. But you can ask for it at any point, and it will be reviewed regularly.You need to be able to show that you cannot manage the single monthly payments.Housing benefit is part of Universal Credit, and most claimants are responsible for paying their landlord themselves.But you can also apply to get a managed payment directly to the landlord, so it doesnt go into your bank account at all.Any part of your rent it doesnt cover will have to be paid by yourself, separately.As of May  around seven per cent of people on Universal Credit had their support paid directly to the landlord.Either you, your representative or your landlord can make this request over the phone, by email or post.In instances of domestic abuse, or when one partner mismanages the Universal Credit payment, you can apply for a split benefit.When a couple are together in the same household with one claim, in very exceptional circumstances it can be ided into two.They are meant to prevent hardship to the claimant and the family.The larger percentage can be allocated to the person with primary caring responsibilities.The DWP says to speak to your work coach about alternative payment arrangements and seeyoure illegible.Today it was revealed that almost half of Brits on Universal Credit are struggling with their finances after nine months.The new system was also reported to be riddled with errors - requiring huge amounts of data and not alerting claimants when theres messages.And mums on the flagship benefits programme told MPs this week that the system penalised single parents.

title: people wont be putting clocks back
story: Many don’t even realise they will wake up on Sunday morning after getting an extra hour of sleep.That is because more than half of UK adults,  per cent, no longer use analogue timepieces or technology.Brits will be waking up on Sunday morning to a home full of digital devices and Internet-connected phones, computers, TVs and appliances that will automatically reset the time themselves.The research was carried out by OSS Technology and it gives an insight into how physically winding the clocks back and fiddling with our watches will soon be a thing of the past.For the  per cent of Brits who say they still own analogue devices, at least  per cent of them have at least one device at home that is an hour out.And for a third of those polled, ignorance is bliss because they don’t even know that British Summer Timeis going to end.OSS Technology surveyed , adults across the UK to find out how they are preparing for the time change this Sunday.This year, Sunday, March , marked the start of BST and clocks went forward by one hour.The change ensures that there is more daylight in the evenings and less in the mornings.Greenwich Mean Timewill resume from the last Sunday in October– when the clocks go back one hour again.To avoid confusion, many use the phrase spring forward in spring, fall back in fall to remember when the clocks change.Clocks around Britain will go back at am on October , this is when BST goes and weto the classic GMT.

title: used condom co op fridge
story: Kenny Moore and friend Michael Bradshaw were disgusted when they made the discovery while on their lunch break in Holton-le-Clay, Lincs.And the pair claim workers had rled through the fridge and discovered another contraceptive.Kenny, , said: I went into the shop to get a meal deal out of the fridge.I got my sandwich, my pork pie, went to get my drink. title: picky roommate ad landlord no vegans

I’d like to think I’m a pretty nice guy - definitely not your typical landlord that everyone hates, I’m pretty laidback with everything, but don’t take the p***.***IF YOURE VEGAN, DONT BOTHER***My room is right above yours, on the second floor. My bedroom is next to the living room upstairs.There is no wardrobe in your room, only a set of drawers, a small table and a bed which is enough for most people.There won’t be a TV in the living room until at least December, as I’m only just coming back from being abroad for  months. I’ll buy one as soon as I can.I can tell you right now thatyou aren’t keen on doing your own dishes oryou’re untidy in general - forget it.I cant be arsed with a   hour party animal either, sorry.After being made aware of the advert, the Vegan Society pointed out that had Alex been trying to rent out the whole house, such discrimination would not be appropriate.However he enjoys a loophole as a live-in landlord and is able to ensure only meat eaters are welcome.A spokesperson for The Vegan Society said: “While we can appreciate that the landlord was aiming for the advert to be humorous, we don’t quite understand why he would be opposed to living with a vegan.“It’s worth noting thathe was letting out a whole house, discrimination would not be appropriate but there is an exemption in certain situations such asyou’re a live-in landlord.“It is a well-known fact that many vegans are good cooks who pay attention to what goes into their meals.Vegans are often happy to cook for their housemates too, which we think might make Alex reconsider his decision to ban them from his home.”SpareRoom, the website where Alex posted his advert, have called his views contradictory and claim they prefer users to be a bit more positive in how they word things.A spokesperson for SpareRoom said: When people are advertising for someone to live with it’s common for them to have preferences in terms of their new flatmate.Saying ‘I’m pretty laid back with everything’, followed by ***IF YOU’RE VEGAN DON’T BOTHER*** feels like a bit of a contradiction.Ultimately, we’d always prefer itour users take people on the basis of who they are, rather than which ‘boxes’ they tick.When Alex was approached for comment, he said: Are you interested in the room or not

title: woman belly button removed sent boyfriend connection mum
story: After her body was mutilated, she bizarrely sent the belly button to her then boyfriend as a “present”.Paulina Casillas Landeros, , from Guadalajara in Jalisco, Mexico, fell out with her family as they disapproved of her way of le.They were unimpressed with her tattoos and extreme body modications such as a back corset – where piercings are created on either side of the spine, laced with ribbons and pulled tight – along with a split tongue.Annoyed they didn’t approve of her lestyle, she decided to remove her belly button out of spite, as it is what makes us human.She then gave it as a weird gt to her then boyfriend in .Since having her belly button removed three years ago, though, Landeros has made up with her family and ultimately regrets her decision, describing it as reckless and impulsive.The HR intern and tourism student explained: I have always had problems with my family, I was not very close to them at the time.Body modications fascinated me, there is something very transcending about them.Describing herself as very angry at the time, she decided to cut all unions from everything and everyone.I wanted to dehumanise myself in a symbolic way, I wanted to do something controversial.She had an operation to remove her belly button, but claims the professional gave me very bad advice on how to take care of the trauma so it got infected.I was suffering, I spent days in bed asI were quarantined. I couldn’t stretch, push, stand up or laugh.It gradually healed itself but not  per cent – it will never close entirely.Even though it was such a painful procedure, Landeros knew exactly what she wanted to do with her removed belly button.The young woman decided to turn it into a – some might say nauseating – token of love for her then boyfriend, Daniel Ramirez.She said: I was very much in love with my then boyfriend he supported me through many dficult times, and he is one of the most influential people in my le.It was something I did in the spur of the moment. We were young and stupid but that’s the way I felt.I put it in a small bag along with a note saying ‘I love you’. It was very emotional.He has kept it and he will keep it forever because he knows the meaning behind it.We are good friends now but we will always love each other.Her relationship with her family has improved since then and Landeros now realises how irreversible the decision to remove her belly button was.She also said: I do regret it when I put myself in my mum’s position, it must have been devastating for her, she was so sad.I can’t imagine how it must feel, your own child wanting to break all their connection to you.If I could go back in time, I wouldn’t do it again, it was impulsive, reckless and I hurt a lot of people.Even though I did it for the wrong reasons, it has now taught me I should think things through before acting and [the scar] is a nice reminder that characterises me.

title: ham pineapples pizza dont contain pork manchester
story: Instead of ham, the stores used thinly sliced processed turkey, according to tests run by food analysts.The shocking findings were revealed by ITV Tonight during a probe into the drastic drop in food sample tests being carried out by cash-strapped local authorities.Some  local authorities in Greater Manchester failed to carry out any food sampling tests of restaurants or takeaways  in the last year, a Freedom of Information request found.The news comes less than five years after the horsemeat scandal, which saw the meat sold as beef in ready meals in major UK supermarkets.At the time The Food Standards Agency was giving councils £.million for testing.But in the - financial year councils werent given a single penny.So this month researchers visited  random takeaways to test their ham and pineapple pizzas.Of the ten outlets they tested, just one sold them a pizza containing pork, according to public analyst Dr Duncan Campbell.Manchester City Council told the programme:It is never acceptable for food to be mislabelled and we will take action in cases where this is detected.Where meat has not been described accurately and businesses have not heeded advice, we have taken forward successful prosecution cases.As a result of this investigation, we will be contacting the businesses concerned.Simon Blackburn, a spokesman for the Local Government Agency, added: The number of trading standards officers that we employ across the UK is around half of what it was in , so half the amount of people unfortunately, they can’t do all the work that they used to be able to do.

title: man hiding 10 pound notes around uk
story: Matt Callanan has spent £, of his own money on a project he hopes will inspire people to do good deeds.So far film-maker Matt has left hundreds of envelopes scattered across Cardf and Dublin, and is planing to target cities in England and Scotland in the future.His project Tenner For Good involves putting a £ or € note in an envelope with two important rules.Number one: Dont spend the money on yourself. Number Two: Do some good with it.Matt stashes the cash in creative spots across the cities, including in bicycle wheels and on roadworks signs.He tries to place them in spots close to charity shops as a nudge to people who pick them up.In one instance he hid an envelope outside a childrens hospital under a bench.Matt told the Huffington Post: “[A man who works in the hospital] saw the envelope, went back in to the workplace, told them the story and they all started chipping in tenners.“He got to £ and he thought: what can we do for the kids They turned it into  Easter eggs and he went back dressed as a bunny and delivered all the eggs to the kids in the hospital.”He added: “I love that domino effect that you can create.“I think my favourite one that’s come out of it, there was this guy in Bristol and he didn’t find any of the tenners but he heard about it and wanted to do his own.“He brought this homeless guy into his house, listened to his story, gave him a cup of tea and on the way out gave him a couple of tenners, wished him well, and then the guy got back in touch with him a few weeks after that and said that he’d now got his benefits sorted, a job sorted and a house sorted.“And it was all because this guy Ben had given him his time and made him feel valued. That was just a lovely outcome.”Matt also teamed up with a local troop of Brownies to deliver thank you cards to doctors and nurses at a local hospital.He said: “And apparently all of these doctors and nurses ended up bursting into tears because it was just such a kind thing for these young girls to do for them.”

title: mum found needle nappy pampers
story: Kayleigh Smith, , bought the Pampers nappy from Co-op and found the needle in the lining while her son Freddie was wearing it.She is now urging other parents to always check their nappies for dangerous items that may have been planted.Kayleigh, from Kinver, West Midlands, took to Facebook to warn others, saying she cant believe whats happened.She wrote: I always buy Aldi nappy’s love them.But I ran out yesterday so went to co-op and brought some pampers paid loads for them actually.Freddie’s just came up to me pulling at his nappy I knew something was bothering him so had a look..To find a needle perfectly bent in the lining of the nappy.I’m fuming.He has scratches on his thigh and bum.Thes some sick f**kers actually doing this shit.Other mums flocked to comment their support on the Facebook post, sharing their concern for the safety of children using Pampers nappies.Hannah James wrote: This is terrible, I’d be furious! Ahh Kay.. hope he is ok  you, poor Freddie😨.. xx.Meanwhile Julie Collett commented: That is disgraceful they need to take them off shelf in co op xx.Others wrote that they hoped the needle found in the nappy was clean, such as Georgia Allen who commented: OMG!!!!! That’s awful hope he’s okay!!! Hopefully the needle was clean! Xxxxxxx.Kayleigh later commented to reassure her friends that Freddie was okay: He’s fine but that could of been dferenthe’d of sat the wrong way or something. I’m fuming I’m getting on to pampers and co-op. I can’t believe I’ve witnessed this shit with my own eyes. Gobsacked.The Facebook post has since had over  shares and over  comments.Kayleigh later told Heart radio station: Im absolutely mortied.To me, it looks like its been threaded through the nappy.Obviously, you dont know whether its clean or dirty.It could have been a lot, lot worse.If hed have sat dferently, or on the side, it could have gone straight in.Pampers said in a statement: We are sorry to hear about this family’s experience: we are in discussion with the family in order to understand what happened. We have requested that the product and packaging are ed for full investigation as soon as possible. Until this is done, we’re unable to provide specic comments on this case.Our number one priority is to ensure that our products are completely safe for babies to use. Our nappies are made to very high standards and we have strict quality checks in place at every stage of manufacturing process.We encourage parents who have any questions or comments about our products to get in touch with us – our UK free line number    .The Sun Online contacted the Co-op but they declined to comment.

title: mum pretended single working benefits
story: Edyta Ratecka, , claimed she was a single mum but was caught out by family snaps she posted on Facebook showing her enjoying holidays with her boyfriend.Polish-born Ratecka had claimed she was a single mum after giving birth to twins in  to swindle £, over a three year period.She was told by a judge she knew what she was doing because she worked in the benefits department of Cardf Council.Ratecka was today handed a -week suspended sentence after pleading guilty to fraudulent activity, making a  representation to obtain benefits, and of dishonesty failing to noty a change in circumstances.Cardf Crown Court heard how the mum began claiming benefits in  while living with Daniel Thomas but a probe was launched when the social media pictures surfaced.She claimed her boyfriend had moved in to help her after the birth of their sons - now aged five - but described their relationship as not good.Ratecka said she knew it was wrong to continue claiming benefits but insisted she had no option as Mr Thomas was not providing for her.Her lawyer, John Lewis, said she was now relying on her -year-old daughter to keep a roof over her head.Sentencing, Judge Tracey Lloyd-Clarke said: “You were working for a benefit section of Cardf council so you were aware of what you were doing.As well as a suspended prison sentence, she was ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work, complete a six-day rehabilitation activity requirement, and to pay £.

title: aldi control heater sky remote
story: Siân-Louise Nightingale, , shared the bizarre video showing how the volume button on her TV remote could switch the heater on and off.The Aldi Flame Effect Heater comes with its own remote control so customers can switch it on and off and control the temperature.However, the medical receptionist quickly learned that her Sky remote was more versatile than she thought after paying £. for the flame-effect heater.She wrote on Aldi’s Facebook page: “Lovely new wall mounted electric fire...“Works on the same remote frequency as our Sky box.“Everytime we increase or decrease the TV volume, the fire tunes on off.”The video shows Siân-Louise, from Nottingham, in her living room pointing the remote towards her wall-mounted fire place.She then presses the volume decrease button on her television remote and the fire appears to turn on.When Siân-Louise presses the same button again the fire then turns off.Then she presses the button faster and it shows the fire turning on and off again.Other customers appear to have experienced this bizarre phenomenon as well.In the reviews section on Aldi’s website, user Jackie said her TV remote can turn the fire on and off.They said: “Good price purchase with real flame effect complete with its own remote control, but the TV remoteinterrupts the fire and switches it off.”Another user, Dean added: “Great fire, one problem other remotes ie Sky turn fire on so every time I use Sky remote fire switches on and heat goes up.”Siân-Louise said she quite liked the quirky behaviour of the fire and that she doesn’t think she will get a refund.She said: “A few people have reported the same and [Aldi] offered for me toit“But I quite like the fire. Although the fire remote doesnt operate the TV.”Aldi responded to her post on Facebook and wrote: “Hi Sian-Louise,you send us a private message about this, our customer services team will be able to advise. Thanks, Aldi UK Facebook Team.”The Sun Online has contacted Aldi for comment.

title: map reveals european holiday hotspots earthquakes volcanoes seismic activity
story: But some regions - many considered among some of the best holiday destinations in the world - are at much greater risk of deadly events linked to seismic activity.Just last night, a huge . magnitude earthquake tore through the Greek holiday isle of Zante, ripping up roads and buildings filled with holidaymakers.British Geological Survey seismologist Margarita Segou told The Sun Online: Greece and Italy have the largest seismic hazard, as we say, which means that earthquakes are more frequent there.However, we have cases of big earthquakes in other countries in historical times, such as Spain.The reason why Greece and Italy are the most seismic areas in Europe is they are areas where seismic plates are forming. The African plate is subdacting, going under, and the European plate we say itsabout cm a year.So all this middle and southern Mediterranean is a very active zone, so it has produced many earthquakes in historical times and in the present.We have stories collected from historical times from a large earthquake magnitude . offshore near Crete in AD which produced a tsunami and reached even Egypt.We have another in AD near Sicily, which devastated some cities in Sicily and caused a tsunami.Large scale earthquakes will continue to go ahead in Italy and Greece. But not only big earthquakes are associated with big risk.She cited last years . magnitude earthquake which struck central Italy as one example of a moderate tremor that can cause carnage.This hit on January  a few kilometres northwest of the town of LAquila, killing  people and laying waste to several ancient towns.She added: Risk comes even from moderate earthquakes, they tend to happen every five years in these countries. They are more frequent than large ones.Last year scientists said they expected an increase in earthquakes due to a tiny decrease in the speed of the planets rotation.A report presented at the Geological Society of America argued that five periods of intense seismic activity throughout history have followed periods of when the Earths rotation slowed.However, Segou did not believe the frequency of the tremors hitting Europe was increasing.Associate Professor of Earthquake Science in the School of Earth Sciences at the University of Melbourne, Mark Quigley has previously told news.au central Italy is experiencing crustal extension.He says: Eastern central Italy is moving to the NE relative to Rome.As a result, this region experiences normal faulting earthquakes as the land is torn apart. The fault systems are short and structurally complex, so the earthquakes are not overly large by global standards.But because the earthquakes are shallow and structurally complex, and because many of the local towns and cities contain vulnerable buildings, strong shaking from these earthquakes has the potential to inflict major damage and loss of le in urban areas.Some  per cent occur around the rim of the Pacic Ocean.The plates - giant rock slabs that make up the Earths upper layer - are always slowly moving.They often collide and slide against each other, according to National Geographic.This impact can be unnoticeable on the surface but can cause immense stress between the plates.When this stress is released, it causes massive vibrations, called seismic waves, often hundreds of miles through the rock to the surface.There are fears that there is a big one on the way after a flurry of volcanic activity in the Pacics Ring of Fire.A study from Calornia says that the cluster of tremors around the planets so-called Ring of Fire- a horseshoe-shaped geological disaster zone - could indicate the big one is due to hit.The research, published in the journal Science Advances, involved analysis of  major earthquakes around the Pacic Ring of Fire between  and .Europe also has a number of volcanoes - some dormant, others active - which have in the past caused catastrophic events and huge loss of le.Among these is Mount Etna, on Sicily, which was first recorded erupting in BC, and has exploded around  times since.This last occurred in  when a BBC crew were pelted with boiling rocks and steam as they filmed the mountainside.Many in Europe also remember the  eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull, in Iceland, which triggered huge air travel disruptions across western and northern Europe.Last year, researchers at the University of Leeds revealed the findings of a study which determined such ash cloud eruptions could occur once every  years.Co-author Dr Graeme Swindles said: In , when Eyjafjallajökull erupted, people were really shocked – it seemed to come completely out of the blue, but the eruption of Grímsvötn, the following year, was an extraordinary coincidence.Although it is possible that ash clouds can occur on an annual basis, the averageinterval for the last , years is around  years.The last time volcanic ash clouds affected northern Europe before the recent event was in ,  years ago – but aviation was much less intense at that time and it simply didnt have the same sort of impact.Our research shows that, over thousands of years, these sorts of incidents are not that rare – but people wondering how likely it is that the  chaos will be repeated in the next few years can feel somewhat reassured.Just this year alone the world has witnessed destructive eruptions in Hawaii, Bali and Guatemala.However, Clive Oppenheimer, professor of volcanology at the University of Cambridge, says there has not been an increase in volcanic activity.He told The : There have been quite a few eruptions in the news lately, so people question whether there’s an increase in rates of volcanism that we’re seeing just now, and this isn’t really the case.Eruptions are happening all the time - some make the news headlines and others don’t.If we look at the statistics back in time, the main thing we see is a reporting bias. There are not many eruptions during World War Two, for example, when people had other things to really worry about.So of course things will flare up in one place or another place and then it will be very much how those eruptions affect people and whereabouts in the world - whether that then becomes newsworthy.

title: sewage drinking water thames bosses
story: Thames Water said today the UKs capital will lose £ million a daydramatic measures arent put in place to save the citys water supply.The population of London is set to rise by two million people in the next  years which could lead to a million litre daily shortfall of water, made worse by climate change reducing natural resources.So Thames Water plans to open a reuse plant at the Deephams Sewage Treatment Works in North East London which will turn sewage into water clean enough to drink - a UK first, the Evening Standard reports.But the plant is not currently planned for everyday use - its intended for times of projected or actual drought.Discussions with the Environment Agency are ongoing about the viability of this plan.After plans to build a new £.billion reservoir in Oxfordshire were rejected by the government in , the plan is being revived by Thames Water.It is intended for water to be shipped down the Thames along the Oxford Canal to ensure taps keep flowing.The reservoir near Abingdon would play a vital role in supplying water to the South East.It will be complete by ,the government approves it.Thames Water also owns the UKs only desalination plant in Beckton, East London, which turns sea water into million litres of drinking water a day during drought.The company has a water resources management plan for the next  years which has budgeted £.billion until .A spokesperson said Thames Water is pledging to reduce leakage from its ,-mile network of pipes.He added: “More needs to be done to protect Londoners from the risk of severe drought.“Restrictions on water use in London alone could cost more than £million a day.”The reuse plant will put million litres of water a day back into the system by passing treated sewage through a desalination membrane to clean it.Its then mixed with reservoir water, treated again and pumped into the network.The spokesperson added: “We wouldn’t consider reusewe didn’t think the water would be good enough.”

story: President Frank-Walter Steinmeier has been invited in a “historic act of reconciliation” to mark  years since the end of World War One.PM Theresa May said: “Remembrance Sunday gives all of us the chance to remember the immense sacrices made in war.“I look forward to welcoming President Steinmeier to this year’s ceremony.”He will also join a service at Westminster Abbey.When The Sun revealed the plans last month, ex-Army chief Field Marshal Lord Guthrie insisted the ceremony was “peculiarly British”.He added: “For the Germans to be there wouldn’t be understood by a lot of people.”But Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright said the move shows “the peace that exists between our two nations today”.The Royal British Legion said it was the Government’s decision who to invite.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
