title: how a couple who met amid the horror of auschwitz found love that lasted a lifetime
story: Lale Sokolov was himself a Jewish inmate in the Nazi death camp where .million perished.Inking identity numbers on those destined for slave labour and eventually the gas chambers meant he would be allowed to live.He had imprinted thousands of innocents in a grim pact with SS monsters to keep himself alive.When the -year-old looked into her “big, black eyes” an overwhelming love filled him in a place where he had witnessed so much evil.He later said of that first encounter: “I tattooed her number on her left hand and she tattooed her number on my heart.”Brave Lale went on to discover that her name was Gita and he risked everything to win the affections of the shy -year-old with the dazzling eyes.Their love story against all odds has been turned into best-selling novel The Tattooist Of Auschwitz.Author Heather Morris spent three years interviewing Lale about his time in the camp — but every conversation would circle back to Gita.Heather recalled: “Lale told me that in that first second he knew he could never love another. He was utterly mesmerised by Gita.”Born Gisela Furman, Gita had been sent to Lale, a fellow Slovakian, to have her existing tattoo redone because it had faded.After the inking, smitten Lale was desperate to see her again — so he summoned up the courage to ask a “helpful” SS officer called Baretski to smuggle letters to her in one of the women’s blocks.Lale described sending the first note as “the best and the most stupid” thing he’d ever done in his le.Heather said: “He knew he was risking both their lives but he still thought it was worth the risk.”And it paid off — the letters led to snatched visits outside Gita’s block, where her friends would form a circle around the pair to give them privacy.The writer continued: “Even when she had her head shaved and was dressed in rags he thought of her as the most beautul thing he ever saw.”Yet Gita was initially against a relationship.Heather, a retired social worker, explained: “What was the point of putting themselves in danger “But Lale always knew he was going to survive and tried to convince her there was hope.”That was an astounding feat of optimism from Lale, who had managed a department store before being sent to Auschwitz in April .On one day alone he watched as all , gypsy inmates of the camp were sent to the gas chambers.Lale also had to work with Dr Josef Mengele, the twisted medic who performed agonising and often lethal experiments on the prisoners.The tattooist was more terried of Mengele than of any other Nazi in the camp, but was required to stand beside him as he selected victims.The doctor would lean into Lale and whisper, “One day, tetovierer , one day I will take you.”Heather said: “No one scared Lale like Mengele. He would take out his gun and hold it to Lale’s head.“Lale would drop his tattooing needle because he’d be shaking.”Despite the wretchedness of his le, Lale always considered himself one of the lucky ones.His position as the “tetovierer” afforded him privileges — extra food and medicine, and a freedom of movement that allowed his love with Gita to bloom.Heather said: “He rationalised his role as the tattooist quite well. He said that the people who came to him were lucky too. “If you were being numbered that meant they weren’t heading straight to the gas chamber.”But when Heather tried to get Lale to go into detail about his feelings concerning his role, he would veer off and talk about Gita.She said: “To him, their love story was all that mattered. I put it to him, ‘Do you realise that you were marking the most iconic symbols of the entire Holocaust ’ He replied, ‘No, it’s about Gita. You tell everyone how much I loved Gita’.”Lale had been working in Bratislava when he heard that all the Jews in his hometown of Krompachy were to be rounded up to be sent to “labour camps”.Young and fit, he ed home and offered himself to authorities, hoping he might save his ageing parents from being taken.He became part of the first transport of Jewish prisoners to Auschwitz, where he was tattooed with the number  and put to work building housing blocks.Soon afterwards he was approached by the incumbent tattooist, Pepan, who askedhe would work with him. Lale knew five languages — useful in the job.Pepan disappeared weeks later and Lale was left with the job. He met Gita in July that year.Their courtship lasted three years. Then, in , as Russian troops moved towards the camp in Poland, the prisoners were moved out.Gita was sent on a so-called Death March along with the other women in the camp, while Lale was moved to a dferent camp in Mauthausen, Austria.There he managed escape by swimming across the Danube and made his way home to Slovakia. He learned that his parents had both died in Auschwitz. And he had no ideaGita was alive.Desperate, he took a horse and cart to Bratislava, the entry point for many survivors ing home, and waited at the railway station for weeks hoping to spot her.Then someone told him to look for her at the Red Cross HQ. On the way there, she suddenly appeared in front of his cart.Heather said: “I honestly worried about that when Lale relayed the story. It’s such a Hollywood ending that I didn’t think people would believe it.“Remarkably, I have evidence from Gita backing it up.“While she never spoke about her time in Auschwitz, Lale convinced her to make a testimony to Steven Spielberg’s Shoah Foundation.“In the video footage she said that she remembered walking down the street in Bratislava with two of her friends when one of them pointed out a horse coming down the street towards them with a tiny little cart on the side with this funny man standing on the back.“She said, ‘I looked up and it was Lale, so I stepped in front of the horse. That is the only time I’ve ever known Lale when he was speechless’.” The pair married in October  and emigrated to Melbourne, Australia, where they had a son, Gary, in .They set up a textile business and made a pact not to tell anyone how they met — with Lale worried he might be seen as a Nazi collaborator because he “helped” them by doing the tattoos.Even their son didn’t know.But when Gita died in , aged , Lale finally felt ready to talk.Heather recalled: “A friend put us in touch — I knew he had a story to tell but I had no idea what it would be.“He was obviously an old man and he said we needed to work fast because he was ready to be with his we again.”Lale died in , three days after his th birthday — and two hours after Heather’s last visit. She said: “The last thing I said to Lale on his last day on earth was, ‘I will never, ever stop telling your story’.”He died too soon to see Heather’s novel become a global smash hit.But Heather said: “Lale would have been so delighted.“I have to pinch myself, really. I’m absolutely astonished by the response to this book.“But I think it’s the hope that’s really resonating with people. Hope out of something so awful.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: mcdonalds human poo london newham
story: Disgusted Ben Terry posted a picture of the human poo on the chains Facebook page.The image shows what appears to be a small piece of excrement lying on the toilet floor at the outlet in Forest Gate, Newham.Wet tissues are scattered beside it on the floor, which appears to be wet.Ben wrote: Actual human poo on the floor in Forest Gate McDonalds. title: zante earthquake west coast greece 6 8 magnitude
story: The massive tremor struck in the dead of night on the country’s west coast, with the holiday isle of Zante – also called Zakynthos – worst affected.Brit tourists were among those caught up in the tremor, which was also felt in Greeces capital, Athens, and as far away as Italy and even Africa.One holidaymaker from Yorkshire told Sun Online how her terried family were left huddling outside their hotel as the building shook.Tracey Archer tweeted to travel agent Thomas Cook: Please do something!! We are stuck in Zante after an earthquake and everyone is outside the hotel in blankets.There’s babies and young children. Please do something, we’re scared and cold.Tracey, , told The Sun Online: Were terried. We’ve just had another bad aftershock and they keep coming.We were stood outside the hotel for about three hours in the freezing cold, scared.There were young children crying and screaming. We felt a quake about .am and later a larger one half an hour later.Were you affected by the earthquake  Email tips@the-sun or call   Tracey - who is staying at the Smartline Margarita Hotel with her partner Luke,  - said the quake knocked sinks off walls, pulled air con units down and shted furniture.She added: The bed was shaking violently for minutes.My partner and I screamed and grabbed each other and he put a pillow over us to protect us as we thought the ceiling would cave.Laura Sallabanks, , from Coningsby, Lincs, said her nine-year-old daughter was left “shaken” after rushing out of their accommodation in the Alykes area.She told Sun Online: “We woke up to a smaller quake, half hour before the big one which set things rattling in our rooms.“The big quake lasted a couple of minutes and felt like the whole building was swaying around us.“There was a loud rumble. I ran through to grab my daughter who is nine and we all rushed to get outside where we sat with the locals for a couple of hours.”The mum described “items thrown from shelves” and the quake leaving “cracked floor tiles and slabs”, admitting: “My poor heart is still pounding!”She added: “We can still feel aftershocks now after eight hours, which feel like dull rumbles.”Other Brits took to social media to tell of their experiences.One wrote: “Standing outside the hotel no clue what to do   Cracks in the building no @ThomasCookUK rep or advice.”Another posted: “Actual earthquake in #zante #zakynthos #kalamaki never experienced anything like that in my le!“Room shook for  seconds, followed by a longer period of vigorous shaking and with items falling off the bedside and around the room.“Electricity is off and everyone evacuated.”" data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width""  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width""  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   quake.png stripallw" "" width"" A third tweeted: “Go to #Greece they said ... have a Nice relaxing holiday they said.“#Zante is lovely this time of year they said...then a cheeky  #earthquake on a full moon.“Rather unsettling. But buildings and the people here seem to be made of strong stuff so... So far, so good.”And another said: Me and my partner are staying in Zante, it woke my partner up, and weve had three aftershocks much smaller, the larger quake has moved several items around the room.Tremors were felt as far away as Italy and AlbaniaDramatic images show how the quake tore tarmac in half near the island’s harbour.Power was lost in the capital and main town, also called Zakynthos.The fire service said rockfalls were reported in another part of the island, where boulders crashed onto a packed beach sending tourists fleeing just last month.And part of a church wall collapsed on the mainland town of Pyrgos, in the southern Peloponnese area.Several of people were treated for minor injuries.Civil protection agency press spokesman Spyros Georgiou said a precautionary tsunami warning was issued.He added: “Were checking out the villages on the island, where there are several older buildings.“The lack of electricity is a problem, but technicians are trying to restore power.”Initial reports suggested the quake hit the Ionian sea, just off the western coast of Greece at just before pm local time.The Greek tourist island, popular with Brits, is understood to have been the epicentre.Greece lies in one of the worlds most earthquake-prone regions, with thousands of quakes recorded every year.But few cause injuries or signicant damage. In , a magnitude . quake on the outskirts of Athens killed  people.Zante has had severe earthquakes in the past, and as a result has a very strict building safety code.

title: debenhams 500m pothole in the road to reinvention
story: This, runs the message, is the unnished truth. Things can only get better.Thats why its the sort of thing that comes much more easily to a newcomer, such as Ms Osborne.She was only appointed to the job in August, so is entirely untainted by everything that has gone before.Instead, her job here is to size up the problem, and then work on making it better.So thats why the loss is so enormous.Its not that Debenhams is shipping buckets of money every day - in fact, its making a small profit - but instead that, as a one-off, its decided that its assets just arent worth as much as they previously thought.In particular, Debenhams has concluded that it should cut the valuation it puts on something called goodwill - a rather amorphous term that tries to put a price on the reputation of a company.

is the latest to hit the benefit as it triggers debt and foodbanks" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Touch-ID-or-Enter-Passcode.jpg" data-tracking"email|share|"CommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT NewsBayard Tarpley said he was told to do everything in his power to shunt claimants of the six-in-one benefit onto a website "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former Universal Credit call handler has claimed he was actively encouraged to get desperate claimants off the phone. Bayard Tarpley said he was handed a deflection script and told to do everything in his power to shunt claimants of the six-in-one benefit onto a website. The claim - flatly denied by the Department for Work and Pensions- is the latest to hit the benefit, whose rollout is blamed for rising debt and food banks. It comes after an audit report blasted DWP managers for presiding over a department in denial. He told Sky News: We were encouraged to end the call sooner so that we could quickly get through things. There didnt seem to be a lot of changes that were specically there to support claimants.  So there was there is something called the deflection script. It was a piece of paper that explains what to do when someone calls in. Evena problem could be solved then and there on the phone we were encouraged to do everything in our power to get them to hang up the phone and do that online. A DWP spokeswoman said: These claims are completely . We take the training of our call handling staff extremely seriously to ensure they are prepared to handle a range of enquiries, regardless of how long they might take – there is no policy to get callers off the phones.” However, the DWP said it does inform customers they can go online and call agents use aids to process claims effectively. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Mr Tarpley told the Mirror: Deflection script is what it was called by managers. It’s what it was called during training and it’s what your team leader would tell you to improve on during -- meetings. I suspect they’re splitting hairs and saying there’s no official document referred to as the deflection script.

title: senior minister praises mirror high
story: NewsSenior minister praises the Mirror for High Street Fightback campaignEXCLUSIVE: Jake Berry said our demands would be at the heart of an upcoming reviewShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politicsGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe minister has commissioned shoe boss John Timpson to conduct a review into how to revive town centres "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA senior minister has praised the Mirror for leading the crusade to save struggling town centres with our High Street Fightback. Jake Berry said our demands would be at the heart of an upcoming review. He said: “The Mirror’s High Street Fightback campaign has really helped to get that wider drum beat going about how all of us have a duty to protect, support and create an environshyment in which we can foster our high streets.” The minister has commissioned shoe boss John Timpson to conduct a review into how to revive town centres which will be published “shortly” with a “robust” Government plan. He added: “All the things you have put in here, John Timpson will be looking at.”  Mr Berry also gave his clearest hint so far that Monday’s Budget would act on online retailers who fail to pay their fair share of tax. Amazon sparked outrage after it emerged it had paid hardly any tax in the UK. Mr Berry said: “We have to recognise Amazon provides a route to market for many small businesses. There’s an acknowledgeshyment taxation around that digital economy needs to change. “The work Government is doing is to look at ways of capturing some of that value. That’s ultimately something for the Budget.”  Refusing to accept an inevitable decline of shopping areas, he went on: “They are the original social netshywork. You cannot get the hug when you shop online and the ability to have a relationship with the people who work there.” We want councils to be able make compulshysory purchases of neglected sites and an end to rip-off parking. Mr Berry said: “I hear the call for additional powers from local authorities, that is why we’ve set up the Timpson review.”  The MP for Rossendale and Darwen, Lancs, also urged councils to have a dialogue with local businesses about parking charges. He said: “Parking should be determined by local authorities but... a period of free parking is crucial for the health of the high street. In my area, traders want an hour or two [of free parkshying] so people with new cash in their pockets can arrive every couple of hours and spend it.” Mr Berry also backed our call to change planning laws which require permission to turn a cafe into a shop, for example. He said: “The system should foster entrepreneurshyship rather than, in some cases, stand against it.”

title: theresa proclaims strictly come dancing
story: NewsTheresa May proclaims Strictly Come Dancing will be fine after Brexit - but nothing  has cha-cha-changedWell thats one worry over with - but nothing has cha-cha-changed where, with talks still in deadlock and warnings a longer transition could cost billionsShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT NewsWell at least thats one worry over with from Dancing Queen Theresa May "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit will pose no threat to Strictly Come Dancing, Theresa May declared today. That means theres one worry over with - but nothing has cha-cha-changed where. Talks with the EU are still in deadlock. The Prime Minister reportedly cancelled a meeting with ministers yesterday as plans werent ready, and there are warnings it will all cost Britain billions of pounds. Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable - who appeared on a Strictly Christmas special in  - had claimed immigration restrictions could deprive the show of talented foreign professional dancers.Sir Vince warned that a “cack-handed” immigration policy could prevent dancers from European Union states appearing on the show after Brexit .But he was mocked and the Prime Minister’s deputy official spokeswoman said: “I think Strictly will be fine.”  During a visit to Brussels on Thursday for talks with EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier, Sir Vince said: “As British society falls apart it could pose a risk to Strictly.” Sir Vince, a keen ballroom dancer, said: “If we have a cack-handed immigration policy like what we have for non-EU citizens, all kinds of perverse decisions could be made.”It came as Sadiq Khan today urged Brussels to begin preparations to delay Brexit.The Mayor of London said this would allow time for a second referendum on membership or a change of government to negotiate a “good deal”.The Labour mayor held talks with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels, saying he wanted to avert a “political and economic crisis”. Mr Khan’s visit was the latest by a politician to Brussels for talks with the EU as the two sides seek a workable Brexit Withdrawal Agreement. Britain is currently due to leave the EU next March. It means there is just five months left to complete a workable Withdrawal Agreement and have it ratied by national parliaments. And talks are still deadlocked over the thorny issue of the Northern Irish border. An EU summit fell through with no deal last week, with another summit with  leaders not scheduled until mid-December. To break the deadlock, Mrs May offered to either extend Britains transition period beyond December  - or accept a backstop plan with no end date that would keep EU customs rules across the UK.  Both plans enrage Brexiteers. More than  Tory MPs have demanded Mrs May drop key aspects of her plan. And today Sir William Cash, chairman of the Commons European Scrutiny, warned Mrs May extending the transition period could add billions of pounds to the poundbillion Brexit orce bill. After talks that lasted an hour in Brussels, Mr Khan said that Mr Barnier had been “willing to listen” to concerns about the negotiations. The mayor said: “I made the point that a bad Brexit deal, or even worse no deal whatsoever, it’s bad for London, it’s bad for our country but it is bad for the EU as well.

title: easyjet leaves blind man stranded
story: NewsEasyJet leaves blind man stranded abroad after he refused to attach unsafe harness to guide dogDavid Ferguson was due to fly back from Portugal when a flight attendant demanded he attach a seat-belt extender to his beloved guide dog JamieShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT NewsDavid Ferguson says his guide dog Jamie has changed his le six years ago"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind man says easyJet left him stranded after he was kicked off a plane when he refused to attach an unsafe harness to his guide dog. David Ferguson, from Bangor in Northern Ireland, was flying back to Belfast with his dog Jamie following a trip to southern Portugal. The pair were scheduled to take the .pm easyJet flight from Faro to Belfast City Airport on theirjourney home when they encountered problems. After boarding the aircraft, David says a flight attendant demanded he attach a seatbelt extender to his dog Jamie - something which David deemed unsafe as it was made for humans and not for dogs. The retired -year-old refused to use the extender because he feared for Jamies safety in the event of a crash.  David and Jamie have previously boarded flights to Gatwick and Spain without issue using a cushioned harness he provides for plane journeys. The safety harness is approved for use on airplanes by the Civil Aviation Authority, David says. David suffers from Usher syndrome, a disorder that causes loss of both hearing and vision, and says he struggled to understand the companys staff.The flight was held up for  minutes while he negotiated with crew - but was eventually booted off the plane. At one stage, a pilot for the airline intervened in the dispute but found nothing wrong with seat belt extender. I was humiliated in front of the people on that aircraft, he said. Ive been with my dog  hours a day since I got him six years ago and as blind people were told to always know where our dogs are at all times.  Theres no way I would put him in danger or allow anyone to put him in danger. The airline effectively left a blind person stranded in the airport with almost no way of getting home. David originally booked his holiday with Thomas Cook and says he was surprised when he discovered that he would be flying with easyJet. After being kicked off the plane, David was left with no alternative but to fork out €for a Ryanair flight back to Dublin. Once there, had to endure a two-hour bus trip to Belfast from the Irish capital. David arrived home at .am thanks to help from his good friend Kenny Tosh who drove him back from the airport. He says his quality of le has improved dramatically since he was given the eight-year-old Labrador back in . He has literally changed my le, David said.  Before I had Jamie I was afraid to leave the house on my own unless someone picked me up. At one stage I walked into a lamppost and I was nearly knocked over. David has demanded airline staff be better informed about the challenges faced by blind people when travelling on their aircraft. If this is how they treat blind people Id be amazed to see how they treat able-bodied persons, he said. An easyJet statement toread: Unfortunately Mr Ferguson and his guide dog were not permitted to travel from Faro to Belfast on September  as he failed to comply with on-board safety regulations surrounding the securing of his dog for take off and landing. “Our policy makes it clear that dogs must wear a standard identying jacket or harness which is provided by the owner, which must be attached to the owners seat belt via the use of an extension seat belt in order to provide an effective level of restraint. “The safety and wellbeing of passengers and crew is always easyJets highest priority.”

title: incredible bravery story sas legend
story: NewsPrince Harrys touching tribute to incredible act of SAS bravery during elite units finest hourEXCLUSIVE: SAS Sergeant Talaiasi Labalaba fought during the Battle of Mirbat in Oman, widely considered the finest hour of the SASShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPrince Harry and Fijis President Jioji Konrote pose in front of a new statue commemorating Sergeant Talaiasi Labalaba, a British-Fijian soldier who lost his le in the  Battle of Mirbat "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailProud is a word Roger Cole doesn’t use often. He is a rare and shyexceptional hero who insists he is nothing of the sort, recalling his SAS career and death-defying deeds asthey were ordinary days in the office. But as Prince Harry unveiled a statue to SAS Sergeant Talaiasi Labalaba in Fiji, Roger felt a rush of pride. He and “Laba” fought together during the Battle of Mirbat in Oman, widely considered the finest hour of the SAS. Roger saw Laba, , single-handedly man a lb field gun, usually crewed by four, to protect the nine-strong band of brothers, as well as locals, from the attack of  enemy soldiers – even after bullets blew away half his jaw. Sadly Roger, now , last saw his Fijian friend zipped into a body bag. And seeing the statue brought all those memories back.  Roger says: “I felt proud to have known Laba and to see him so respected. Really proud. Quite overwhelmed, actually. “This man who was always smiling, always positive even in the worst sshyituations. And he was very steely – he easily coped with everything. He deserves more recognition than he got. “Hopefully, having the world’s cameras on Laba’s statue means more people will appreciate what he did. Because within my memories of him smiling and sadness at losing him, it’s always irked me that he didn’t get the Victoria Cross.”  In  the SAS was secretly stationed in Oman to bolster Britain’s ally the Sultan and protect Arabian oil fields from communist guerrillas, trained by Russia and China, called the Adoo. As part of Operation Jaguar, their first mission was to win the hearts and minds of locals in Mirbat, a small coastal town. Roger, then a -year-old lance corporal, says: “None of the locals knew anything about the outside world so they were very taken aback to see us. “We were medics who helped give their babies medicine and set up football teams for the kids. Laba had a really special way with children.”  At .am on July , the day the men were due to fly home, Roger was sleeping at the house they were based in when he was woken up by a fellow shysoldier. Roger recalls: “He said, ‘I think we’re being attacked’. And I said, ‘bugger off’. Then I heard ‘boom boom boom’, looked out and saw bombs landing all over the place.” Roger got dressed and manned a machine gun as the enemy advanced to a nearby fort on the town’s outskirts. He says: “We’d immaculately trained for this. Laba ran  yards under fierce fire towards the gun pit outside the fort.” Thick mist cut visibility to  yards and when Roger saw  figures through the gloom, he “knocked them down”. But waves of enemies, armed with Kalashnikovs, rocket-propelled grenades and mortars, kept advancing.  Roger says: “With swirling mist, and enemy constantly coming up from trenches, I felt asI was in a World War One film. Around  minute s later the radio crackled with a message from Laba, ‘I’ve been hit. I’m still OK’. He was horrendously injured, yet carried on firing, knowingthe Adoo got hold of that gun we were all f***ed.” The gun, normally fired at long-range, was being used like a rle as the enemy were so close to the barbed wire perimeter of the gun pit. Sgt Sekonaia “Tak” Takavesi, a fellow Fijian, ran to Laba’s aid in another feat of bravery which the SAS also believes is deserving of a Victoria Cross. Roger says: “One hundred and fty guys were shooting at him from  yards, bullets and grenades were bouncing off the ground. “Tak ran like a rugby player, ducking, dodging and weaving to get to his line. And he made it. I still can barely believe what I saw.” Tak found Laba wounded to his chin. And while Tak was himself shot in the back and shoulder, he leaned against sandbags and kept firing. At .am the -pounder gun fell silent.  Commanding officer Captain Mike Kealy, aged only , decided to run to the gun pit and trooper Tommy Tobin volunteered to go with him. Mike ordered a mortar to be fired close to the gun pit. “It could have gone seriously wrong and wiped out our own men,” says Roger. “But it worked - it frightened the enemy back.” Mike and Tommy reached the pit and found Laba had been shot in the throat. A message came across the radio to Roger: “Laba is dead.” Tommy’s jaw was also blown off and he died later back in Britain. “It didn’t sink in at first,” admits Roger. “Adrenaline is so high, focus fully on the task ahead, there’s no time for emotion.“ Yet even at the height of battle, Roger spent time treating local casualties. A helicopter arrived to help, but came under fire and had to turn back. Then as the fighting raged, a radio message told Roger two jets were on their way. “They asked, ‘How many enemy ’ I replied, ‘A f*****g lot’.” The planes fired rockets and machine guns, and dropped lb bombs. One was damaged and left the battle. The other ran out of ammunition. Roger says: “When I got back on the roof with Corporal Bob Bennett, we saw a large troop marching towards us. We looked at each other and said, ‘Bloody hell’. It was our Zulu moment. “I knew this could be our last half hour. I had  rounds left. Bob had ten. “And that’s when pictures of my we Pauline and daughter Natasha, only nine months old, came into my mind. I would never let the enemy take me alive – I would’ve shot myself with my last bullet.” The sound of helicopters eventually broke through the gunfire. A -men back-up SAS team arrived and the Adoo started to flee. Roger says: “Years later, when I was writing my book, I spoke to someone on the other side. He told us we fought off  men that day.” The choppers were loaded with dead bodies and casualties. Roger continues: “I saw Tak walking to the helicopter to make sure Tommy got inside, even though he had four bullet holes in him.” The battle was won. Yet silence surrounded their victory. Roger adds: “I wanted to say, ‘We have just won a war’. Yet no one knows a thing about it. All of the Mirbat survivors are still good friends – almost family. “We have a bond that can’t be broken, and that gave us strength. The only thing we want is to see Laba properly shyrecognised. Prince William unveiled a statue in the SAS camp at Hereford, but the public can’t see that. “Prince Harry immediately said he’d unveil Laba’s new statue in Fiji. “He knows Laba is an SAS legend. Maybe now we can get our government to realise the same thing and give him the posthumous Victoria Cross.”SAS Operation Storm: Nine Men Against Four Hundred by Roger Cole and Richard Belfield, published in paperback by Hodder  Stoughton pound..

story: NewsMeghan reveals beautul thing Harry did on morning of wedding - with a nod to mum DianaPrince Harry and Meghan have revealed details of their nuptials for the first timeShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-meghan-harry-leave-chapel-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex have revealed new details about their wedding day in recorded messages for an exhibition at Windsor Castle. title: salisbury cathedral part new axis
story: NewsopinionIs Salisbury Cathedral part of a new Axis of Evil That spire seems to have an awful lot to answer forShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  OCT Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIran did a deal. Iraq got bombed back to the Stone Age. North Korea was invited to tea. Into the void where the Axis of Evil once terried the world, a new existential threat to civilisation has been born. And it has a spire  metres tall. Unbeknown to the , tourists who visit it each year, it seems that Salisbury Cathedral is built on an inter-dimensional whirlpool which sucks evil down towards hell like sand in an hour-glass. The presence of these unwitting pilgrims, walking widdershins around the cloisters, merely speeds up the spiritual centruge.Hence the bemusement of Russian spies who, on an entirely-heterosexual visit under  names to the East End of London, found themselves dragged towards the bewitching building. They broke free of its unearthly tractor beam only when they dropped a bottle of perfume that Ruslan had bought as a gt for his mother, and was unfortunately past its sell-by date.Caught in the Salisbury swirl, the liquid mutated into a battlefield nerve agent with unforeseen deadly consequences when it was dropped on the doorstep of a building that happened to be home to a Russian defector. They didnt get to see the spire. Which is a shame, because theyd heard it was the tallest in Britain.  The vortex is felt across the world. It drew a team of  assassins from Riyadh to Istanbul, where CCTV was disabled when an unfortunate journalist tripped and fell over a discarded bone saw, several times, and then cut off his own face and thew it down a well. It also compelled his accidental murderers to flee before the Turkish authorities could persuade them to headbutt a bullet, develop a sexual attraction to mincers, or perhaps most suicidally of all, announce they were taking up careers as journalists.The evil eddy even forced an otherwise-gentle and liberal soul entirely in tune with st century social norms to scream UGLY BLACK B******! at a Windrush migrant.The more cynical corners of the internet have whispered that Ryanair flights are the twisted children of Salisburys malevolent maelstrom, producing miniaturised tides of despair and misery, but the companys official ouija board insists in the face of all the evidence that it is just a coincidence.  Now it appears Salisburys undertow to the underworld has drawn someone all the way into the cathedral itself, there to smash two holes in the specially-toughened glass box in which lies one of only  remaining original copies of the Magna Carta.At time of writing no-one has been charged in relation to the Get Carta incident, but there are three madcap theories of who could be responsible:. A grammarist insistent on adding the definite article to the documents customary description, becausethe is written on the bloody thing people cant not use it . The ruler of a nation in political crisis who wants to add a th clause stating Brexit means Brexit on the basisthey didnt know what it meant in the th century she cannot be blamed for making it up as she goes along in the st . Nicholas Cage on one of his many flights of fancy, trying to crack a hidden medieval code that links the Founding Fathers to Jesus secret lovechild, whose ultimate descendant turns out to be Indiana Jones dad.  Of course, thats all ridiculous, isnt it  As mad as finding someone in Old Sarum wants planning permission for an underground shark tank, or that Kim Jong Un has moved his embassy to Middle Wallop. Or genuinely thinking that because both Porton Down and a village called Palestine are in the vicinity, Salisbury must be on speed-dial to the Devil himself. There are no forces of evil. Salisbury is no more be a wormhole to the netherworld than it is a coral atoll in the South Pacic. Whoever tried to steal the Magna Carta was too dumb to realise it was alarmed, it would disentegrate within  minutes and would be harder to sell on than Philip Greens used undercrackers. Evil is a supernatural force which means some people are born beyond redemption - destined for corruption and amorality, and liablecaught to be crucied, electried, poisoned or shot because theyre something other than human. But evil is just an excuse.Humans are merely bad. They make bad decisions and do bad things, making bad excuses along the way. Vladimir Putin ordered the elaborately-dficult murder of Sergei Skripal because he thought the defector was evil, and evil deserves the effort. The Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia ordered the elaborately-messy murder of Jamal Kashoggi for the same reason. And people like the Ryanair racist arent evil, either. Theyre angry, ignorant, unsocialised outcasts, often sick and usually screaming at the world for not being nicer to them. When we say something is evil we refuse to take responsibility. We say it was out of our hands when the Twin Towers fell or the policeman was kned or the terrorists got through. We dont say: How did we make that terrorist  Why dont we spend money on people who do bad stuff  What has to change before we accept that guy other there goes to the toilet just like I do Whoever tried to steal the Magna Carta, whoever is sending bombs to Donald Trumps enemies, whoever strokes Tommy Robinsons cancerous ego is not evil. Theyre us, with a few things gone wrong. A lost job, a last straw, a loose wire.If we stop saying its evil -we stop saying maybe thats just Salisbury for you - we might be able to fix it. You dont solve problems with an excuse.

story: NewsSir Philip Green snapped with Las Vegas showgirl.. and now hes lying low in ArizonaEXCLUSIVE: The picture, obtained by the Mirror and taken in Las Vegas, reveals the billionaire in his pomp before his name was dragged into a string of scandalsShareByNick SommerladChristopher BucktinNicola Bartlett:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPhilip Green with his arm round a woman at a casino in Las Vegas"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith his trademark grin, Sir Philip Green wraps his arm around the waist of a young woman in little more than lingerie and angel wings. The picture, obtained by the Mirror and taken in Las Vegas, reveals the billionaire in his pomp before his name was dragged into a string of scandals. As we today tracked down Green to Arizona, there were demands for the tycoon to be stripped of his knighthood. He is facing calls to drop his injunction preventing reporting of a string of gagging orders signed by former staff, who allege he bullied and sexually and racially harassed them. Three months after he launched a pound, legal bid to silence the , Green issued a statement this week in which he insisted: “I categorically and wholly deny these allegations”.  The Las Vegas photograph shows Green wearing one of his much-loved fancy dress outfits, a frilly shirt unbuttoned to the waist, with the unidentied young woman at his side. It was allegedly taken in the Bellagio Hotel on Halloween in . An onlooker told the Mirror: “It was early evening when I saw Sir Philip leaving the Bellagio with two young women. “It was Halloween and everyone dresses up in America, so it seemed normal. He was clearly off to aand got into a car. “There was no sign of Lady Green. He was holding this woman close and clearly enjoying himself.”  Tonight Green appeared to be lying low after being named in Parliament as the businessman behind the injunction. The Mirror spotted the Topshop tycoon’s poundmillion private jet parked discreetly at Tucson International Airport in Arizona. Green was seen talking on his mobile as he strolled in the US state. A source said: “It’s no secret Phil’s love of Arizona. He gushes about the place.  “It has year-round sun and allows him to escape the stresses of his business. “Whenever troubled has flared before he has been known to head to Tucson, leaving behind his place in Monaco or his yachts. Normally where ever his Gulfstream is, Phil is not far away.” The Gulfstream GER had left Las Vegas on Sunday destined for the Arizona city, but as it was making its approach it erted to Los Angeles.  Little more than  hours later, at .am on Monday, it left LAX to make the -minute journey to Tucson. Green’s aircraft is described as the “holy grail of private jets”. It can fly non-stop from Hong Kong to New York. It was delivered in , weeks before the Green family’s Lionheart superyacht arrived. The vessel is understood to have cost poundmillion. Green, often snapped with A-listers such as the late Dirty Dancing actor Patrick Swayze, has a transport collection that also includes a speedboat, a helicopter and other yachts.  He is a regular in Tucson, where he visits the Canyon Ranch wellness resort at the foot of Santa Catalina Mountains. It thought he used the retreat during the BHS scandal. In  he sold the chain to investors with no retail experience. A year later it went to the wall with , job losses and a poundmillion pension fund black hole. Meanwhile the #MeToo scandal continued to swirl around Green today. A hashtag of pinknotgreen swept across social media, with calls for a boycott of Green’s shops, including Dorothy Perkins, Wallis and Burton. On Thursday, ex-Labour minister Peter Hain told the House of Lords he felt it was his “duty” to name Green due to the “serious and repeated” nature of allegations. He told Parliament he had “been contacted by someone intimately involved in the case of a powerful businessman using non-disclosure agreements and substantial payments to conceal the truth about serious and repeated sexual harassment, racist abuse and bullying”. A barrister claimed Lord Hain’s conduct was “completely improper”, but the peer said it was “the right thing to do”. He later told BBC Newsnight: “I considered it extremely seriously before I said it. I’m discharging myas a parliamentarian, and what concerned me about this case was wealth, and power that comes with it, and abuse.”  Parliamentary privilege protects MPs or peers from being prosecuted over statements made in the Commons or Lords. Green said after Lord Hain named him: “I am not commenting on anything that has happened in court or was said in Parliament today. “To the extent that it is suggested that I have been guilty of unlawful sexual or racist behaviour, I categorically and wholly deny these allegations. “These settlements are confidential so I cannot comment further on them.” Thespent eight months investigating accusations against the tycoon. But on Tuesday the newspaper was prevented from revealing the existence of non-disclosure deals by a interim injunction issued by the Court of Appeal. Women and Equalities Select Committee chair Maria Miller, who has called for reform of such deals, today suggested it was time to “consider whether NDAs are actually outlawed”. She added: “Unfortunately they’ve become so misused that some feel they can do anything as long as they can afford to pay for the victims’ silence, and that is no way for our legal system to work.”

story: NewsUK weather: Met Office issues snow and ice warnings for today and tomorrow as biting Arctic front moves inForecasters say its time to get the warm winter clothes out as Britain braces for a dramatic drop in temperaturesShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video bitterly-cold-winds-snow-ice-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailForecasters have issued snow and ice warnings this weekend as the country is gripped by freezing temperatures and bone-chilling Arctic winds. The cold snap will bring an end to the largely mild start to autumn, with people advised to dig out their warm winter clothes over the weekend. A yellow warning for snow and ice is in place for northern Scotland from pm on Friday, while another for ice takes effect in Northern Ireland from am on Saturday. Even in southern parts, where temperatures are forecast to be around C , the wind chill factor means it will feel several degrees cooler, forecasters said.  Forecasters warned of patchy ice and slush affecting some upland routes as well as rail and road disruption. Snow may dust the tops of hills in the Pennines in northern England, Snowdonia in north-west Wales, the North York Moors, and across the Scottish Highlands. Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: Snow building up over the higher routes, some icy patches for the north of Scotland as well as Northern Ireland to watch out for first thing Saturday.  It will be a fairly chilly start, with temperatures widely close to freezing and that means youll perhaps have to scrape your car windscreen and youll see a frost in place first thing. Eastern parts are likely to see hail, showers and strong winds throughout Saturday, with the odd chance of a thunderstorm. Gritters are on standby across the country, with a number of councils posting pictures of their fleets online. Motorists have been warned to take extra care on the roads and anticipate widespread frost as thermometers drop to - Celcius overnight in higher parts.  Met Office forecaster Bonnie Diamond added: We have had a pretty mild October so far and a warm start to autumn in places so it will be a big change for everybody as we go through the weekend. Certainly its time to get the warm winter clothes out. Three-day UK weather forecast Today : Showers are expected across Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland throughout the day, and there will be some rain in the south-east to start. Showers in Scotland could turn wintry, with snow possible, but mainly over high ground. There will be sunny spells at times too. A cold northerly breeze. Tonight : Wintry showers will continue over the high ground of northern Scotland tonight. Showers too for Northern Ireland and Wales and some coastal areas through to dawn. It will be largely clear and dry across the central belt. Frost will develop for many into the early hours. A cold northerly breeze. UK Outlook : Another cold day tomorrow, with showers for the east coast, northern Scotland, Wales and the south-west. These could be wintry, especially in Scotland. Scattered showers in the south-east by the evening. Sunday will be dry and sunny for many, but with the chance of showers on the east coast. Breezy.

title: young children spend twice long
story: NewsYoung children spend twice as long looking at screens as playing outside, study findsBy the time they reach the age of seven, children will have been looking at screens for the equivalent of  days – an average of four hours every dayShareCommentsByRichard Jenkins:,  OCT NewsIt also emerged more than half of a child’s screen time is described as ‘mindless’ - spent without family or friends, in solitary, screen-based activities"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYoung children spend twice as long looking at screens as they do playing outside, a study has found. By the time they reach the age of seven, children will have been looking at screens for the equivalent of  days – an average of four hours every day. But just  days, or an average of just over an hour and a half a day, will have been spent playing outdoors. It also emerged more than half of a child’s screen time is described as ‘mindless’ - spent without family or friends, in solitary, screen-based activities. The research, of , British and Irish parents of children aged up to seven, was conducted by Persil, and found three quarters have used a screen to entertain their youngsters so they can get on with other tasks. But six in  admit this behaviour, while convenient, could negatively affect their child’s creative thinking and ability to problem solve.  Sir Ken Robinson, a leading expert in education, creativity and human development and chair of the Good Child Development Advisory Board, said: If you’re an adult now, how much time did you spend as a child playing outdoors, making up games on your own or with friends, dashing around, taking tumbles, all for the sheer fun of it  “Until recently, children spent many hours every week on this sort of physical, imaginative, social play. “’Real play’ like this is not only enjoyable: it is vitally important in young lives. “Research has long shown that it has essential roles in the balanced development of all children and young people.” The study also found  per cent of parents wish their children would spend more time playing outside as opposed to in front of a screen.

title: woman 23 removes belly button
story: NewsWoman, , removes her belly button and gives it to boyfriend as presentWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Body modication fanatic Paulina Casillas Landeros underwent the painful surgery to dehumanise herself in a symbolic way - but she now regrets itShareCommentsByAliki KraterouLucy Clarke-Billings:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPaulina said she knew she wanted to give the body part to Daniel as an ultimate token of love "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old woman removed her belly button and gave it to her ex-boyfriend as a present. Body modication fanatic Paulina Casillas Landeros, from Jalisco, Mexico, underwent numerous surgeries such as a back corset - which involves piercings on either side of the spine - and a split tongue. She later decided to remove her belly button as it is what makes us human before giving it as a present to her then boyfriend Daniel Ramirez, in . But following the removal three years ago, she says she ultimately regrets her decision describing it as reckless and impulsive.  The HR intern and tourism student said: I have always had problems with my family, I was not very close to them at the time. Body modications fascinated me, there is something very transcending about them. I was very angry, I wanted to cut all unions from everything and everyone. I wanted to dehumanise myself in a symbolic way, I wanted to do something controversial. I underwent an operation done by a professional but he gave me very bad advice on how to take care of the trauma so it got infected. I was suffering, I spent days in bed asI were quarantined, I couldn’t stretch, push, stand up or laugh. It gradually healed itself but not  per cent - it will never close entirely.  Paulina said she knew she wanted to give the body part to Daniel as an ultimate token of love. She said: I was very much in love with my then boyfriend, he supported me through many dficult times, and he is one of the most influential people in my le. It was something I did in the spur of the moment, we were young and stupid but that’s the way I felt. I put it in a small bag along with a note saying I love you, it was very emotional. He has kept it and he will keep it forever because he knows the meaning behind it. We are good friends now but we will always love each other.  Paulina says her relationship with her family has now improved. I do regret it when I put myself in my mum’s position, it must have been devastating for her, she was so sad, she said. I can’t imagine how it must feel, your own child wanting to break all their connection to you. If I could go back in time, I wouldn’t do it again, it was impulsive, reckless and I hurt a lot of people. Even though I did it for the wrong reasons, it has now taught me I should think things through before acting and it’s a nice reminder that characterises me.

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: dundee council to spend 10000 more on christmas decorations
story: Dundee City Council is to spend more than £, on Christmas decorations for the city centre this year – an extra £,.Members of the council’s city development committee will be told next week that a sum of £, has already been approved for the festive display.In a report to go before members on Monday, the local authority’s new director of city development, Robin Presswood, will explain that the cost of putting up Christmas lights will be above the council’s budget of £,.But Lynne Short, convener of city development, said she was pleased money is in place to provide decorations for the city.She said: “Unfortunately, like everything , the cost of the Christmas decorations has increased.“However, we are glad that we have been able to find the money in this time of constrained budgets to be able to put up our Christmas decorations again this year.“I am pleased that we are to be able to continue with our tradition this year and make this happen.”Bill Newcombe, chairman of the City Centre and Harbour Community Council, also welcomed the spend. He said: “We’re trying to make the city centre a place that people will want to visit – it’s good to know it will be decorated again this Christmas.”Mr Presswood said in his report: “Work will be undertaken to ensure future years’ costs reflect the allocated budget.“Given the limited timescale available, the executive director of city development in consultation with the convener, Lord Provost Borthwick, the Labour Group, Conservative Group and Liberal Democrat Group, accepted this tender.”

title: dundee linked with move for ex ross county and dundee united defender
story: Another former Ross County player could be on Jim McIntyre’s radar.It emerged on Wednesday, Martin Woods has been training with Dundee and could be the new Dens Park boss’ first signing.And now there’s speculation defender Paul Quinn could also join up.Like Woods, Quinn played under Jim up in Dingwall. The -year-old moved to Dundee United last year but his appearances were limited by injury and illness.And he would have to prove his fitness before being given a contract with the Dark Blues.Meanwhile, the matter of who will be the new assistant boss at Dundee could be resolved soon.Billy Dodds is the manager’s preferred choice but as is now clear his arrival would be unpopular with many fans.Others in the frame include Aberdeen coach Barry Robson and possibly even former Dee skipper, and one-time manager, Barry Smith.Whoever gets the nod should be in place for next week’s clash with Celtic.

title: dundee united is perfect platform for striker pavol safranko
story: Robbie Neilson says Dundee United are giving star striker Pavol Safranko the perfect  to show off his ability.The Slovakian international joined the Tangerines on loan while former boss Csaba Laszlo was still in charge to regain the form that saw Aalborg shell out a six-figure sum last summer.The move to Denmark hasn’t worked out but four goals in his last five games during his loan spell at Tannadice has helped new boss Robbie get off to a positive start with a win and a draw in his first two games.And the new United gaffer is delighted he’s got a player like Safranko to lead the line, evenhe accepts the Slovakian is likely to only be a one-season wonder.He said: “I’ve been very impressed with Pavol, very impressed. He’s definitely one of our key players.“He links the game well, has good strength, very good mobility and a good attitude as well – the rest of the players really like him as well which is a big thing.“You need a striker to lead the line for you that can handle the physicality because the game gets like that in Scotland.“Last Saturday there were a few hefty challenges but he stood up to it. I have been impressed, I think he’s a very good player.“He got a good move before but has had a dficult time since.“However, we’ve given him a  to rebuild himself and I think it’s a good window for him to show what he can do.”Neilson has also revealed he’s upped the tempo in training since taking the reins to get the best out of his new squad.He added: “We have just been trying to get the intensity up in training a wee bit.“When I came in, I looked at all the data at what they had done previously and what I felt I would try to implement because I have dferent ideas about what to do.“I just felt we needed to do something a wee bit dferent to try to get a spark in the team and get some enjoyment.“What you want to do when you come in is work them really, really hard to get them as fit as you can as quick as you can. But you also have to realise where their base is so you can minimise injuries.“We have been pretty lucky with that with only Paul Watson getting a wee tweak in his thigh last week.“The base was good, it was fine and I was happy with it but I just wanted to bring more intensity to training to make it shorter and sharper.”

title: dundee united women on the road to the top after league win

title: freeze the fees teles drive to have ninewells parking fees frozen delivered to indigo hq
story: A petition has been delivered to a private parking firm calling for it to perform a U-turn on plans to raise its fees at Ninewells Hospital.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd, which runs parking facilities on behalf of NHS Tayside as part of a private finance initiativecontract, announced earlier this month its intention to raise charges from November .The cost of a single visit to the hospital’s car parks will go from £. to £., while staff permit prices will also rise for the third time since .A Tele campaign – Freeze the Fees – backed by a petition, called for the firm to keep charges at existing levels until at least November next year. More than , people signed the petition.The Tele took those signatures to Indigo’s headquarters in Watford, accompanied by a letter from Tele editor Andrew Kellock, and submitted them to the company.The letter, addressed to the firm’s directors, read: “Although we appreciate that it is your right to review charges on an annual basis, through the terms of the contract you signed some  years ago with NHS Tayside, we believe that adding further cost to what is already an expensive and potentially worrying time for people visiting the hospital, is unacceptable.“Your company records show that you made a profit of more than £ million last year, which is directly attributed to a previous rise in parking fees.“Given these profits, we do not feel that a further rise is justied, at a time when most household budgets continue to be squeezed and people’s ability to pay such charges is diminished.“When we were informed of your plans to raise parking fees, we launched a campaign, backed by a petition, called Freeze the Fees. This is calling for your company to keep parking charges at Ninewells Hospital at existing levels – set in November last year – until at least November next year. A total of , people signed this petition, via our website and through forms we included in recent editions of our paper. I enclose a list of the names we received – some chose to remain anonymous.“We feel this sends a strong message to your company that this proposed rise should not take place.“It is also our understanding that the Scottish Health Secretary, Jeane Freeman, is writing to you to ask for a rethink.“The will of the general public and our country’s top politicians is clear – a rise in parking fees at Ninewells Hospital should not go ahead on November .“We urge you to take these views into consideration and do the right thing by the people the hospital serves – and Freeze the Fees for the coming year.”Ms Freeman’s letter, sent to Indigo managing director Phillip Herring, read: “As you will be aware, the Scottish Government abolished car parking charges at all publicly-owned NHS hospital car parks from December  .“Hospital car parking charges put an unnecessary financial burden on those attending hospital for treatment, their families and hospital staff.“Increases of any size add to this burden and I therefore urge you to reconsider the decision to increase car parking charges at Ninewells Hospital and to commit to freezing parking charges at existing levels, as set in November .”Indigo has refused to answer questions from the Tele on its plans, but claims the fees are governed by its contract with NHS Tayside.

title: george cran roles reversed as pressure now on dunfermline and allan johnston as dundee united look to gather momentum
story: With the first quarter of the season behind them, it’s fair to say it’s been a bumpy ride so far for Dundee United.Often coaches will use this point of the campaign as the first real chance to assess how things are going as they prepare to meet sides for the second time in the league.For the Tangerines, though, a report card right now can’t possibly tell the whole story with Csaba Laszlo not even lasting to this marker in charge of the team.And to judge his replacement Robbie Neilson after just two matches in charge wouldn’t be fair.However, comparing the fortunes of their next opponents Dunfermline since they met on the opening league match of the season makes for interesting reading.That’s because the atmosphere around Allan Johnston’s Pars since they finally overturned a -match winless run against the Tangerines to continue a lightning-fast start to the campaign has flipped almost completely.While the Tangerines struggled and stumbled under Csaba’s reign at the start of the season, Johnston was enjoying seeing his side inflict a - win at Tannadice to make it five wins from five games played after a % record in their Betfred Cup group.That was with an impressive  goals scored and included a deserved - win at Premiership Dundee.Now, though, Johnston faces a new man in the other dugout with intense scrutiny from fans now on him rather than his opposite number.After their perfect start to the campaign, it took Dunfermline another five matches to register a second victory in the Championship and have only racked up eight points from eight matches since.In the process they only managed six goals, conceding  and being dumped out of both the League Cup and Irn-Bru Cup on penalty shoot-outs.Going into Saturday’s game at East End Park, the Pars sit adrt of the play-off places, four points behind United in fourth place.Another poor result, after their - home defeat to Queen of the South at the weekend, will leave them well behind in the race for the top four, heaping all the pressure on Johnston and his side.And the contrast with Neilson, his United players and the atmosphere among the support is stark.After kicking off his reign with a - victory at Partick Thistle, the new gaffer led the Tangerines out for the first time at Tannadice at the weekend.Despite not managing to make it two wins from two, drawing - with Inverness CT, the players were boosted by the biggest home crowd of the campaign.The belief that Neilson can repeat the feat of promotion to the Premiership he achieved at Hearts is clear among the United support.Optimism throughout the stands has been almost completely absent over the past couple of seasons but the hope is now with former chairman Stephen Thompson having departed, and Neilson taking the reigns, good times might be on the horizon.And the ideal time to fuel that fire is now with games against sides below them in the table coming up – Dunfermline this weekend and then Queens the week after.With both the sides coming up in indferent form, points are a must to keep the good feeling flowing.Because what Dunfermline did show the last time the teams met, despite what’s happened since, is they can actually beat their bogey side United.What Neilson can’t afford now is to let the early momentum slip away, something that happened with both Ray McKinnon and, more obviously, Csaba Laszlo.Preventing that could well show the fans’ early optimism is justied come the season end.

title: jim mcintyre expected to make first dundee signing ahead of celtic clash
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is swtly set to bolster his options by adding free agent Martin Woods to his squad.The former Ross County midfielder has been without a club since leaving Partick Thistle after their relegation last season and is set to be re-united with his former gaffer.McIntyre signed Woods twice while gaffer in Dingwall, the first a month after taking charge before the -year-old had a spell down south with Shrewsbury before ing north.Woods has been training with the Dark Blues since last week and was present at last night’s - defeat to Hearts.He’s expected to become the manager’s first signing before next week’s home clash with Celtic.Woods was previously linked Dens back in the summer but the move never materialised under the reigns of then-manager Neil McCann.

title: kilmarnock submit complaint to sfa over referee chiefs letter to dundee fans over jordan jones dive
story: Kilmarnock have submitted a formal complaint to the Scottish Football Association after referee chief John Fleming claimed Jordan Jones had ed against Dundee.The Northern Ireland winger agreed to accept a two-match ban after he was charged with simulation following his side’s win at Dens Park.However, the Rugby Park outfit made it clear their player had not acted in a premeditated manner when he won his side a controversial spot-kick, insisting the only reason they had not challenged the punishment was a lack of supporting TV evidence.Fleming has angered Killie bosses after he wrote to a Dundee fans group saying Jones of threw himself to the ground “solely to deceive the referee”.In his letter to the Dundee Supporters’ Association , which was revealed by the Tele, Fleming stated: “The two-match suspension offered to the player has been accepted by the club which, in my opinion, clearly indicates the player committed an act of simulation during the match. On accepting the two-match suspension, the club, in my opinion, are accepting the player committed the act, solely to deceive the referee.”However, that has enraged Kilmarnock, who released a statement which read: “The original correspondence from the DSA to the SFA and Mr Fleming expressing concern over the suitability of Steven McLean to take charge of Kilmarnock matches was completely baseless and cast unfounded aspersions on the referee’s character.“It is highly ironic that after another organisation has cast aspersions on the integrity of a match official, it is our club which has been the subject of negative remarks.”Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fans-group-writes-to-top-officials-over-referee-steven-mcleans-links-to-kilmarnock embed # secretfpZWClsvb" data-secret"fpZWClsvb" width"" "" title"#Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: we must avoid avoid pressing self destruct button urges dundee boss
story: Jim McIntyre praised his players’ work-rate but felt they again pressed the self-destruct button as his first home game in charge ended in defeat to Premiership leaders Hearts.Jim’s Dens Park bow got off to the worst possible start as his Dark Blues fell behind to an Oliver Bozanic free-kick after just two minutes.Twelve minutes later they were - down as Jambos skipper Steven Naismith found the back of the next.The start to the second half was even worse as Steven MacLean made it - just  seconds after the restart and put the game beyond the home team.The lapses that led to all three goals were frustrating for Jim but at least he felt able to praise some of the work put in, particularly in the first half.“The players showed plenty of character at - down, the way it’s been going recently it would be easy to just feel sorry for yourselves and just collapse but we never,” he said.“We had a real go at it in that first half and created some good opportunities ourselves. That’s the positive to take, but we need to eradicate self-destructing.“There was a bit of that and their might be a bit of pain before it gets better but it will get better, that’s for sure”Dundee squandered a great opportunity to get back in the game when Calvin Miller fired wide from the penalty spot with the score at - and Jim felt other chances went begging as well.“Hearts are a good side, but you can’t stand off teams. You’ve got to make sure you are taking the game to them as well.“I felt they did that on a number of occasions and we drove Hearts back and created opportunities. When you get those opportunities that lts the belief to go to the next level.“Obviously the penalty is the biggest chance and we have a great chance with a head as well and we should have done better at that.“The pleasing thing is we didn’t crumble and feel sorry for ourselves.”Things don’t get any easier for Jim and his players and after a free weekend, next up at Dens Park are Champions Celtic a week tonight.After that one comes what is already looking a massive clash at Motherwell on Saturday week.
